children.name: to answer a teacher, parent etc in a rude way
talk back x
children.definition: answer back/talk back to answer sb rudely, especially a teacher, parent etc when they criticize you or tell you to do sth: trả treo, cãi lại
examples: ▪ don’t talk back. it’s rude.
answer sb back: trả treo ai, cãi lại ai
▪ we were all scared of mr williams, but here was a girl who actually answered him back.
talk back to sb: trả treo, cãi lại ai
▪ don’t talk back to your mother like that!

children.name: back talk x
children.definition: back talkalsoback chatbritish  rude remarks that sb makes when they answer their teacher, parent etc: câu trả lời xấc láo, trả treo, cãi lại
examples: ▪ i don’t want any excuses, complaints, or back talk.
▪ any more of your back chat and you’ll have to stay behind after school.

children.name: when sb is rude to teachers, parents etc
disrespectful c2
children.definition: disrespectful rude, especially towards sb you should respect, for example your parents or sb in authority: không tôn trọng, bất lịch sự
examples: ▪ a letter from the school arrived, saying that joey had been both disobedient and disrespectful.
disrespectful to
▪ in chinese culture, it is considered disrespectful to both the living and the dead to live near a burial ground.
disrespectful aboutbritish
▪ he thought i was being disrespectful about his country.
it is disrespectful (for sb) to do sth
▪ some older people think it disrespectful for strangers to call them by their first name.
disrespect[t] to offend or behave in a rude way towards sb: thô lỗ, thiếu tôn trọng
▪ the ambassador said it had not been his intention to disrespect the us government.
▪ some students do feel that teachers disrespect them.

children.name: cheeky b2
children.definition: cheekyuk/ sassyus behaving in a way that is a little rude, especially when this is amusing or annoying – used especially about children : hỗn, xấc
examples: i don’t like teaching that class - the kids are all so cheeky
what do you mean, i’m fat? you cheeky devil!
she's got such a cheeky grin.
don't be so cheeky!
she was sassy and smart, and all the kids liked her
becky was a sassy, rambunctious new york girl he’d met when visiting his aunt.
a sassy brat.

children.name: impertinent x
children.definition: impertinent formal rude and showing no respect for sb in authority, especially by saying things or asking questions about sth that it is not your right to know or discuss: xấc xược, xấc náo
examples: ▪ by now he had gotten used to reporters’ impertinent questions about his private life.
▪ could i ask how old you are, or would that be impertinent?
impertinence[u]
▪ he had the impertinence to suggest i was not raising my children properly.
▪ we will not tolerate such impertinence.

children.name: impudent x
children.definition: impudent formal sb who is impudent, especially a child or young person, is rude and has no respect for people who are older or more important: thô lỗ, thiếu tôn trọng
examples: ▪ she didn’t think the child’s questions were endearing -- just impudent.
▪ on the cover was a picture on an impudent boy sticking out his tongue.
impudence[u]
▪ he looked at me with a mixture of impudence and hostility.anh ấy nhìn tôi với sự pha tạp và thù địch

children.name: insolent x
children.definition: insolent formal very rude to sb in authority and appearing to have no respect for them, especially by not doing what they tell you to do :thô lỗ, thiếu tôn trọng
examples: although she didn’t actually say anything offensive, her expression was sulky, insolent, and hostile.
the girl’s only response was an insolent stare.|don’t be so insolent!
insolence[u]
when i was young, such insolence would not have been tolerated.khi tôi còn trẻ, sự dửng dưng như thế sẽ không được dung thứ.

children.name: irreverent x
children.definition: irreverent showing a lack of respect for someone or something who people are supposed to respect – used especially about comedy programmes and newspaper articles : thiếu tôn trọng
examples: an irreverent look at the week’s events
his irreverent sense of humour

children.name: impolite b2
children.definition: impolite not following the rules of accepted social behaviour, especially when someone does this without realizing it - use this especially about the things that people do or say, rather than about people themselves.impolitesounds rather formal ::không lịch sự
examples: in senegal it is considered impolite if you do not share your food.
it is impolite to do sth
it is impolite and inconsiderate for people to drop in uninvited

children.name: abrasive x
children.definition: abrasive seeming rude or unkind because you say what you think very directly, so that people are annoyed or offended:thô lỗ
examples: harris was abrasive and arrogant
anson’s abrasive personality has landed her in trouble many times in the past.

children.name: bad-mannered x
children.definition: bad-mannered/ ill-manneredespecially writtenbehaving in a rude and unpleasant way, especially because of never having been taught how to be polite :cư xử thô lỗ
examples: her children are incredibly bad-mannered -- she should be more strict with them.
ill-mannered movie-goers talked and took cell phone calls during the picture.
as soon as some english people go abroad, they seem to change into bad-mannered, insensitive oafs
ill-mannered movie-goers talked throughout the entire picture.|it was very bad-mannered.

children.name: discourteous x
children.definition: discourteous formal not behaving in a polite way.discourteoussounds very formal and is often used when talking about being careful not to upset someone’s feelings - use this especially about people’s remarks or behaviour: không lịch thiệp
examples: it would have seemed discourteous to refuse his offer.
it would seem discourteous to refuse her offer.
discourteous to
he claimed that the officer had been discourteous to him.
he did not wish to appear discourteous towards his host.

children.name: unpleasant c1
children.definition: unpleasant to deliberately behave in a rude and unfriendly way towards sb:gây khó chịu
examples: be unpleasant
he can be very unpleasant when he’s in a bad mood.
it isn’t necessary to be that unpleasant, mike.
be unpleasant to
she was shocked at how unpleasant the children were to their mother.

children.name: loutish x
children.definition: loutish rude, loud, and unpleasant - use this especially about people’s behaviour: thô lỗ
examples: the behaviour of some politicians in debates is simply loutish and intimidating.
they considered my boyfriend to be loutish and a bit stupid.'
loutish behaviour

children.name: not polite a2
children.definition: not polite not following the rules of accepted social behaviour, especially when someone does this without realizing it - use this especially about the things that people do or say, rather than about people themselves:không lịch sự
examples: you weren’t very polite to her.
it is not polite to do sth
i was tired, but i thought it might not be polite to leave so early

children.name: rude b1
children.definition: rude b who isrudeupsets or offends people by not following the rules of good social behaviour and not considering other people’s feelings:thô lỗ, bất lịch sự
examples: ▪ what a rude man! he just ignored me when i said ‘good morning’.
▪ i don’t mean to be rude, but could you tell your children to keep quiet?
▪ he’s one of the rudest people i’ve ever met.
rude to
▪ i know you’re upset, but there’s no need to be rude to your mother.tôi biết bạn đang buồn, nhưng không cần phải thô lỗ với mẹ bạn.
rude about
▪ are you being rude about my cooking?
it is rude to do sth
▪ it’s rude to interrupt people when they are speaking. khó mà làm gián đoạn mọi người khi họ nói chuyện.
it is rude of sb to do sth
▪ i thought it was very rude of her not to answer my letter
rudely[adv] c1
▪ blair rudely pushed his way to the front of the line.
rudeness[u]
▪ please forgive me for my rudeness the other day.

children.name: words for describing behaviour, remarks etc that offend people
offensive b2
children.definition: offensive speaking or behaving in a way that is likely to upset or offend sb : gây xúc phạm
examples: his remarks are offensive to african-americans.
offensive language
throughout the football game a small section of the crowd was chanting offensive slogans.
the bbc received a number of complaints about the offensive remarks made during the interview.
deeply offensivevery offensive:
these pornographic magazines are deeply offensive to women.
offensive to
your comments are offensive to all jews.
offensively[adv]
as usual, he got drunk and behaved offensively towards the guests.

children.name: insulting x
children.definition: insulting behaviour, remarks etc that are insulting offend sb a lot because they show a lack of respect for them or for their ability, honesty etc:
examples: ▪ it’s insulting when people assume i must be a racist because i’m from the south.
deeply insultingvery insulting
▪ i find your criticism deeply insulting.
insulting to
▪ advice that is extremely insulting to unemployed people

children.name: be an insult to b2
children.definition: be an insult to/biː ən ˈɪnsʌlt tuː/  to offend a particular person or group of people by showing little respect for their intelligence, ability, beliefs etc:xúc phạm ai đó
examples: ▪ leaders described the mosque’s destruction as an insult to muslims.
be an insult to sb’s intelligence/ability etc:
▪ the lesson was awful. it was an insult to our intelligence.
▪ if i didn’t finish this meal it would be an insult to your superb cooking.

children.name: objectionable x
children.definition: objectionable sth that is objectionable is likely to offend people because it is morally unacceptable or very unpleasant: chướng tai, gai mắt
examples: ▪ i thought the bedroom scenes were pretty objectionable and unnecessary.
▪ our goal is to get rid of many of the objectionable features of capitalism.
highly/deeply objectionable
▪ i find it highly objectionable to have to sit near people who are smoking.

children.name: yob x
children.definition: yob/jɒbǁjɑːb/  british a young man who is rude, noisy, and sometimes violent:người đàn bà thô tục, bạo lực
examples: ▪ a dozen yobs stood outside the pubmọt tá thanh niên đứng bên ngoài quán rượu.
▪ residents complained that yobs had been vandalizing their gardens.
yob culture: văn hóa bạo lực
tv programmes, films, and other forms of entertainment that involve rudeness and unintelligent behaviour.
▪ our tv screens have been taken over by so-called yob culture.

children.name: jerk x
children.definition: jerk/dʒɜːʳk/  especially american an annoying person who behaves in a stupid way, for example by behaving in a rude and unpleasant way:cư xử thô lỗ
examples: ▪ ignore him. he’s just a jerk.bỏ qua cho anh ta. anh ta cũng chỉ là một tên thô lỗ.
▪ he’s an unprofessional jerk who’s always pestering the women in the office.
real/total jerk: cư xử thô lỗ
▪ her husband was being a real jerk about the divorce.chồng cô thực sự là một kẻ điên rồ thực sự về li hôn.

children.name: lout x
children.definition: lout a man or boy who behaves in a rude and violent way:
examples: a few foul-mouthed louts in the crowd were shouting racist abuse.
only a lout would treat a woman that way..
lager loutsbritish young men who drink too much beer and behave in rude or violent way
we stood at the bar being jostled by some thick-necked lager louts.

children.name: to do sth rude without seeming embarrassed
have the nerve c2
children.definition: have the nerve/ have the cheekuk  if sb has the nerve to do sth, they do sth that you think is so rude that you are surprised they did it: có gan
examples: have the nerve to do sth
▪ he forgot our anniversary and then had the nerve to ask what i got him when i reminded him about it.
have a nerve/cheekuk/have (some) nerve
▪ he’s got a cheek, coming back at midnight and then expecting me to cook his dinner.
what a nerve/cheekuk/what a nerveus
▪ what a nerve! i hope you didn’t give him the money!

children.name: have the gall to do sth x
children.definition: have the gall to do sth if sb has the gall to do sth, they do sth that you think is very rude and unreasonable: dám trơ tráo làm gì, "mật"
examples: ▪ i can’t believe he had the gall to ask you for money.
▪ ruth was always on the phone and yet she had the gall to tell me off for making one call

children.name: take the liberty of c1
children.definition: take the liberty of doingsthformal to do sth that will have an effect on sb else, without asking their permission
examples: i took the liberty of booking theatre seats for us.
